column1: 8017`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/water/supp_info/arcConRpt/2012cnstRpts/sept/20120906_Kenmore_48w.pdf`Success`Success`6`6`Not a fillable PDF.`       DEPA RTM EN T OF WATER MANAGEM EN T   C ITY  OF CHICAGO      CUSTOMER NOTICE INFRASTRUCTURE RENEWAL PROGRAM               September 6
column4: I am providing you with information regarding a  water construction project in your neighborhood. This is part of our approach to renewing our  city’s aging infrastructure. I see this as an opportunity to partner with you our customers. As part  of this partnership
column5: I want to be certain you are well informed about the project. You should  know where to call if you have any questions or concerns.     Our crews will soon be installing 1
column6: 609 feet of 8-inch water main in N. Kenmore Avenue
column7: from  W. Granville Avenue to W. Thorndale Avenue. The old pipe dates back to 1890
column8: and needs to be  replaced.    We are coordinating with Alderman Osterman’s office
column9: and he has made clear we are to put great  importance on your convenience and the quality of life in this neighborhood through the whole  term of this project. Good communication is the key.     I have asked my staff to assemble the attached information for you and to monitor the project  closely. We know that construction always involves inconveniences and noise. We will do  everything possible to minimize inconvenience and noise and to conduct ourselves as good and  thoughtful neighbors in the course of our presence on your street.     If you have questions or comments about the project
column10: please feel free to contact Assistant  Commissioner Tom LaPorte at 312-742-1021 at any time
column11: you may leave a message.     I am also asking you to consider the enclosed information about our MeterSave Program and our  Basement Flooding Partnership (BFP).     Sincerely
column12: Thomas Powers  Commissioner     cc:   Alderman Harry Osterman                     48th Ward    1 0 0 0   E A S T   O H I O   S T R E E T
column13: C H I C A G O
column14: I L L I N O I S     6 0 6 1 1        Do you wonder what was happening in 1890?  That’s the year the old water main was installed  beneath your street.  Among other things:                         CY YOUNG IN ACTION      Idaho and Wyoming became states.     The first U.S. college-level dairy school opened at the University of Wisconsin.     W.B. Purvis patented the fountain pen.      Congress created the Weather Bureau.    Rubber gloves were used in surgery for the first time.     X-rays were discovered by Wilhelm Rontgen.    Cy Young pitched and won his first major league baseball game.    The literacy rate in the United States was estimated at 13.5%.    Rose Kennedy
column17: and Dwight D. Eisenhower were born.                  KENMORE AVENUE WATER PROJECT          PROJECT DESCRIPTION     Project:  The Department of Water Management will soon be installing 1
column18: 609 feet of 8-inch  water main in N. Kenmore Avenue
column19: from W. Granville Avenue to W. Thorndale Avenue.    Reason:  The old main consists of 6-inch pipe
column20: and we want to expand capacity. Further
column21: the old  main dates back to 1890 and needs to be replaced.      Timing:  We will begin installing the new water main shortly
column22: and expect the work to be  completed by late December 2012. Restoration will follow in late May 2013. Dates may change  depending on weather and other factors. If there is any appreciable change
column23: we will notify you.    Traffic: We will allow traffic to flow on Kenmore Avenue outside of our working hours.  When  we are working in the street
column24: we have to close it to traffic for reasons of safety. You will always  be able to reach your home or business
column25: even if it means putting a metal plate in place.  Outside  of working hours
column26: a lane will be left open for local traffic only.     Parking: We will post our work area for “No Parking” as needed
column27: during work hours. We are  agreeable to parking outside of those hours
column28: but will have to insist that cars be moved by the start  of the next workday. We will try to preserve as much parking as we can.     CONTACT NUMBERS   24-HOUR SERVICE AND INFORMATION LINE                                                 ALDERMAN HARRY OSTERMAN   3-1-1   773-784-5277   312-742-1021   ASSISTANT WATER MANAGEMENT COMMISSIONER TOM LAPORTE       FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS               What if there is a problem?  There are always surprises in any construction project.  If you  have any concerns or questions
column29: you can ask our foreman in the street.  You can also call  Assistant Commissioner Tom LaPorte directly at 312-742-1021.  His cell is on the voicemail  message
column30: in case it’s off hours.    Can I park when you’re not working? We have no problem with you parking outside of our  working hours.  We have to insist that cars be out of our way at the start of the workday.     Will this ever end?  Yes.  As a matter of fact
column31: the job is slated to conclude in late December.  Restoration will follow in late May 2013. We always hesitate to promise specific dates
column32: since we  are at the mercy of other factors like weather and emergencies elsewhere in town.    Will you shut my water off? Yes
column33: maybe a couple of times. When we switch over the services  from the old main to the new main
column34: we interrupt service. We give you 24-hour notice when this  is to happen.  In any construction project
column35: there is also a risk that an old pipe will break.  They  can be fragile. This may necessitate an emergency shutdown.  If we do this
column36: we will let you know  what is happening
column37: even though we may be unable to give prior warning.    Why should I be nice about this?  The crew working in the street will work hard to be good  neighbors
column38: and to respect both your convenience and your quality-of-life.  By working together
column39: we can complete this important project as friends working for the improvement of our  community.               DOES YOUR BASEMENT FLOOD?     The Department of Water Management would like to work with you and your neighbors to  reduce the risk of basement flooding.  We are promoting a collective response as the only  strategy—homeowners joining together on a neighborhood basis to work with us on  practical steps (public and private) to protect your property and peace of mind.    Want to learn more?  http://www.cityofchicago.org/watermanagement/bfp   DEPA RTM EN T OF WATER MANAGEM EN T   C ITY  OF CHICAGO                  What is MeterSave?    MeterSave is a program to encourage Chicago homeowners to voluntarily install meters to  monitor water usage. Meters allow single family and two-flat homeowners to pay for only the  water actually used
column40: encouraging efforts to save water and money while protecting one of our  most precious natural resources.    Water charges in non-metered homes are tied to factors such as building size
column41: lot-size and  number of plumbing fixtures. Metered homes are billed according to actual use. This means that  with minimal effort
column42: participating homeowners could save money on their water bills.                Homeowner Incentives   Non-metered homeowners participating in MeterSave are eligible for the following:    A 7-year guarantee that the home water bill will be no higher than it would have if the meter   had not been installed. Bill will not exceed the assessed rate for that year.     Choice of one of the following (while supplies last):   rain barrel
column43:     water meter monitor (a refrigerator magnet that shows water usage)    outdoor water conservation kit or      And
column44: two of the above incentives if a whole block volunteers!   indoor water conservation kit   Frequently Asked Questions:   How and when do I sign up?   Interested non-metered single family and two-flat homeowners may visit www.metersave.org
column46: or call 312-744-4H2O. Please have your 12-digit account number ready.  Space is  limited based on funding availability and the number of volunteers.     What will it cost to participate?  The City of Chicago Department of Water Management will install a water meter complete with  the automatic meter reading (AMR) technology in your home FREE of charge.    AMR technology allows readings to be transmitted via wireless radio technology to Water  Management vehicles as they drive by
column47: eliminating the need for readings to take place inside the  home.  Bills will be issued bi-monthly and reflect only the actual amount of water used.     Do I have to be current on my water bill?  Yes.  Homeowners must be current on payment plan and water bill to participate in this limited  time offer of a 7-year guarantee.    For payment plan information call 312-744-4H20 (4426).      1 0 0 0   E A S T   O H I O   S T R E E T
column48: C H I C A G O
column49: I L L I N O I S     6 0 6 1 1            When can I have a meter installed?  Online meter installation scheduling is available at www.metersave.org  Otherwise
column50: Water  Management will contact you to schedule a time for meter installation.      Small changes made by Chicagoans can have a tremendous impact on the sustainability of  our water supply
column51: such as:     Turn off the faucet while brushing your teeth or shaving.  This can save over 500 gallons  per month per person.    Install high-efficiency
column52: low-flow toilets.  Toilets alone consume 26% of household water  consumption.  A leaky toilet wastes 200 gallons of water per day.    Install high-efficiency washing machines. This can save energy and water consumption.    Fill the sink with dishwater instead of washing dishes with an open tap.  This saves 25  gallons per wash.    If you own a dishwasher
column53: wait until you have a full load to run it.  Dishwashers typically  use half the energy
column55: and less soap than washing dishes in the sink.    Garden with plants that are native to Chicago.  This can reduce outdoor water use by 20- 50%.    Use rain barrels to capture rainwater for watering lawns and gardens.    Use a timer or a rain sensor to monitor lawn irrigation: Sprinkler systems use thousands  of gallons of water per cycle.  Installing a timer or rain sensor will save money and water by  preventing needless watering.         WATER   Our Most Precious Resource   Lake Michigan has lost almost 32 trillion gallons of water--the equivalent of over 45 million  Olympic-sized swimming pools of water-- over the past decade. Our region could face severe  water shortages by 2050 if we fail to take decisive action.     More than half of water consumption in Chicago occurs within homes.   Over 5.4 million people-- 44% of the population of the State of Illinois
column56: depend on the Chicago  Department of Water Management to provide a reliable supply of drinking water from Lake  Michigan.     Volunteer for a meter today to save water and money!           Please go to www.metersave.org     By phone call 3-1-1

column29: in case it’s off hours.    Can I park when you’re not working? We have no problem with you parking outside of our  working hours.  We have to insist that cars be out of our way at the start of the workday.     Will this ever end?  Yes.  As a matter of fact
column30: the job is slated to conclude in late July 2013.  Restoration will be completed in late August 2013. We always hesitate to promise specific dates
column31: since we are at the mercy of other factors like weather and emergencies elsewhere in town.    Will you shut my water off? Yes
column32: maybe a couple of times. When we switch over the services  from the old main to the new main
column33: we interrupt service. We give you 24-hour notice when this  is to happen.  In any construction project
column34: there is also a risk that an old pipe will break.  They  can be fragile. This may necessitate an emergency shutdown.  If we do this
column35: we will let you know  what is happening
column36: even though we may be unable to give prior warning.    Why should I be nice about this?  The crew working in the street will work hard to be good  neighbors
column37: and to respect both your convenience and your quality-of-life.  By working together
column38: we can complete this important project as friends working for the improvement of our  community.               DOES YOUR BASEMENT FLOOD?     The Department of Water Management would like to work with you and your neighbors to  reduce the risk of basement flooding.  We are promoting a collective response as the only  strategy—homeowners joining together on a neighborhood basis to work with us on  practical steps (public and private) to protect your property and peace of mind.    Want to learn more?  http://www.cityofchicago.org/watermanagement/bfp   DEPA RTM EN T OF WATER MANAGEM EN T   C ITY  OF CHICAGO                  What is MeterSave?    MeterSave is a program to encourage Chicago homeowners to voluntarily install meters to  monitor water usage. Meters allow single family and two-flat homeowners to pay for only the  water actually used
column39: encouraging efforts to save water and money while protecting one of our  most precious natural resources.    Water charges in non-metered homes are tied to factors such as building size
column40: lot-size and  number of plumbing fixtures. Metered homes are billed according to actual use. This means that  with minimal effort
column41: participating homeowners could save money on their water bills.                Homeowner Incentives   Non-metered homeowners participating in MeterSave are eligible for the following:    A 7-year guarantee that the home water bill will be no higher than it would have if the meter   had not been installed. Bill will not exceed the assessed rate for that year.     Choice of one of the following (while supplies last):   rain barrel
column42:     water meter monitor (a refrigerator magnet that shows water usage)    outdoor water conservation kit or      And
column43: two of the above incentives if a whole block volunteers!   indoor water conservation kit   Frequently Asked Questions:   How and when do I sign up?   Interested non-metered single family and two-flat homeowners may visit www.metersave.org
column45: or call 312-744-4H2O. Please have your 12-digit account number ready.  Space is  limited based on funding availability and the number of volunteers.     What will it cost to participate?  The City of Chicago Department of Water Management will install a water meter complete with  the automatic meter reading (AMR) technology in your home FREE of charge.    AMR technology allows readings to be transmitted via wireless radio technology to Water  Management vehicles as they drive by
column46: eliminating the need for readings to take place inside the  home.  Bills will be issued bi-monthly and reflect only the actual amount of water used.     Do I have to be current on my water bill?  Yes.  Homeowners must be current on payment plan and water bill to participate in this limited  time offer of a 7-year guarantee.    For payment plan information call 312-744-4H20 (4426).      1 0 0 0   E A S T   O H I O   S T R E E T
column47: C H I C A G O
column48: I L L I N O I S     6 0 6 1 1            When can I have a meter installed?  Online meter installation scheduling is available at www.metersave.org  Otherwise
column49: Water  Management will contact you to schedule a time for meter installation.      Small changes made by Chicagoans can have a tremendous impact on the sustainability of  our water supply
column50: such as:     Turn off the faucet while brushing your teeth or shaving.  This can save over 500 gallons  per month per person.    Install high-efficiency
column51: low-flow toilets.  Toilets alone consume 26% of household water  consumption.  A leaky toilet wastes 200 gallons of water per day.    Install high-efficiency washing machines. This can save energy and water consumption.    Fill the sink with dishwater instead of washing dishes with an open tap.  This saves 25  gallons per wash.    If you own a dishwasher
column52: wait until you have a full load to run it.  Dishwashers typically  use half the energy
column54: and less soap than washing dishes in the sink.    Garden with plants that are native to Chicago.  This can reduce outdoor water use by 20- 50%.    Use rain barrels to capture rainwater for watering lawns and gardens.    Use a timer or a rain sensor to monitor lawn irrigation: Sprinkler systems use thousands  of gallons of water per cycle.  Installing a timer or rain sensor will save money and water by  preventing needless watering.         WATER   Our Most Precious Resource   Lake Michigan has lost almost 32 trillion gallons of water--the equivalent of over 45 million  Olympic-sized swimming pools of water-- over the past decade. Our region could face severe  water shortages by 2050 if we fail to take decisive action.     More than half of water consumption in Chicago occurs within homes.   Over 5.4 million people-- 44% of the population of the State of Illinois
column55: depend on the Chicago  Department of Water Management to provide a reliable supply of drinking water from Lake  Michigan.     Volunteer for a meter today to save water and money!           Please go to www.metersave.org     By phone call 3-1-1

column1: 18246`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/water/supp_info/arcConRpt/2017construction/jul_2017/20170724_105th_Vincennes_19w.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`                    RE:   Water Main Replacement Project #1701140    July 24
column3: In coordination with Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s Building a New Chicago infrastructure investment  program
column5: I would like to provide you with information about an  upcoming water main construction project in your neighborhood.    By late July 2017
column6: Department of Water Management (DWM) and Benchmark Construction  Company crews will begin the work to install 537 feet of new 8-inch and 262 feet of new 12-inch  water main in W. 105th Place
column7: from S. Church Street to S. Vincennes Avenue and S. Vincennes  Avenue
column8: from W. 103rd Street to W. 107th Street. The old water main dates back to 1896
column9: and needs  to be replaced.    If you would like to receive regular email updates about the progress of the project
column10: please go to  BuildingANewChicago.org to register for the WaterALERT program.  Simply enter your name
column11: email address and the project identification number at the top of this letter.   By signing up for the WaterALERT emails
column12: you will be notified as the project enters each new  construction phase – from our mobilization of equipment onto the site
column13: to the installation of new  pipes
column14: to the final restoration of the street.   When we are working in the street
column15: we may close or limit it to traffic for safety reasons
column16: but you will  always be able to reach your home or business.  Outside of working hours
column17: a travel lane will be left  open for local traffic only.    We will post our work area for “No Parking” as needed during work hours (generally 7am-4pm).   Parking outside of those hours will be allowed
column18: but cars will need to be moved by the start of the  next workday.  We will try to preserve as much parking space as possible.   We know that construction always involves inconveniences and noise. We will do everything  possible to maintain your quality of life throughout these projects
column19: and conducting ourselves as  good and thoughtful neighbors in the course of our presence on your street.    Should you have any questions or concerns
column20: you can either ask the construction foreman during the  project
column21: or call any of the following numbers:    •  24-Hour City Service and Information Line:  311  •  19th Ward Office: 773-238-8766  •  DWM Office of Public Affairs:  312-744-6635      Genwmnot03032016          Flushing after Your Service Line has been Connected to the New Water Main     When we switch over the services from the old main to the new water main
column22: we will interrupt water  service.  We give you 24-hour notice when this is to happen.  However
column23: in the event of an emergency  shutdown during construction
column24: we may not be able to give you prior warning.   Now that your old water main has been replaced and your water service has been connected to the  new water main
column25: it is important to flush your plumbing of any sediment
column27: including  any lead to maintain water quality.     Sediment
column29: including any lead may collect in the aerator screen located at the tip of  your faucets.  These screens should be removed prior to flushing.  (1) Please find the closest available tap (an outside  hose spigot
column30: laundry sink faucet or bathtub) to where  the water comes into the home that is not used for  drinking water. Fully open the cold water tap and let  the water run for at least 5 minutes.  Next flush any  other cold water faucets on that floor for at least 5  minutes.   (2)Move to the next highest floor and repeat.  (3) Move to additional floors in sequence and flush          any taps or faucets for at least 5 minutes.      If you have any questions or concerns about your water quality
column31: or if you would like your water  tested
column32: please call us at 311.  For additional advice and information visit  http://www.epa.gov/il/advice-chicago-residents-about-lead-drinking-water.   Routine Flushing  If your water line has been idle or stagnant for more than 6-hours
column33: it is advised that you flush for at  least 5 minutes to maintain water quality.  This may include flushing the toilet
column34: taking a shower and  doing laundry.     MeterSave  Lastly
column35: if you don’t already have one
column36: I ask you to consider the installation of a water meter in your  home to help you save money on your water bill.   For more information on this free program
column37: go to  www.metersave.org.   Thank you in advance for your patience and cooperation during this important infrastructure  improvement project.     Sincerely

column1: 18210`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/water/supp_info/arcConRpt/2016construction/jul_2016/20160714_McVicker_Meade_Moodys_45w.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`                   Sewer Main Replacement Project #7216   July 14
column3: In coordination with Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s “Building a New Chicago” infrastructure  improvement program
column5: I would like to provide you with  information about an upcoming sewer main construction project in your neighborhood.     In August
column6: the Department of Water Management’s crews will begin work to install a new  sewer main in N. McVicker Avenue (George-330’ north)
column8: and in N. Moody Avenue (George-330’ north). The old sewer dates back to 1920 and  needs to be replaced.     When we are working in the street
column9: we may close it to traffic for safety reasons
column10: but you will  always be able to reach your home or business.  Outside of working hours
column11: a travel lane will  be left open for local traffic only.     We will post our work area for “No Parking” as needed during work hours (generally 7am- 4pm).  We are agreeable to parking outside of those hours
column12: but cars will need to be moved  by the start of the next workday.  We will try to preserve as much parking as possible.    We know that construction always involves inconveniences and noise. We will do  everything possible to maintain your quality of life throughout these projects
column13: and  conducting ourselves as good and thoughtful neighbors in the course of our presence on  your street.     Should you have any questions or concerns
column14: you can either ask the construction foreman  during the project
column15: or call any of the following numbers:       24-Hour Service and Information Line:  311    45th Ward Office: 773-286-4545    DWM Office of Public Affairs:  312-744-6635   Lastly
column16: if you don’t already have one
column17: I ask you to consider the installation of a water meter  in your home to help you save money on your water bill.   For more information on this free  program
column18: go to www.metersave.org.     Thank you in advance for your patience and cooperation during this important  infrastructure improvement project.          Sincerely
